hints.label: rem-extinction-inevitable
hints.title: Why Extinction is Inevitable (Eventually)
hints.content:
596: :label: rem-extinction-inevitable
597: 
598: The use of **unbounded Gaussian noise** means:
599: 
600: $$P(\text{all } N \text{ walkers cross boundary in one step} \mid S) > 0$$
601: 
602: for ANY state $S$, no matter how safe. This is because Gaussian tails extend to infinity, so there's always a positive (though perhaps tiny) probability of a coherent, large-deviation event.
603: 
604: Therefore:
605: - **Absorption is certain:** $P(\text{reach } \dagger \text{ eventually}) = 1$
606: - **No true stationary distribution** on $\Sigma_N$

hints.label: def-qsd
hints.title: Quasi-Stationary Distribution (QSD)
hints.content:
614: :label: def-qsd
615: 
616: A **quasi-stationary distribution** is a probability measure $\nu_{\text{QSD}}$ on the alive state space $\Sigma_N^{\text{alive}} := \{S : |\mathcal{A}(S)| \geq 1\}$ such that:
617: 
618: $$
619: P(S_{t+1} \in A \mid S_t \sim \nu_{\text{QSD}}, \text{not absorbed}) = \nu_{\text{QSD}}(A)
620: $$
621: 
622: for all measurable sets $A \subseteq \Sigma_N^{\text{alive}}$.
623: 
624: **Intuition:** $\nu_{\text{QSD}}$ is the "equilibrium conditioned on survival." If the swarm starts from $\nu_{\text{QSD}}$ and survives for one more step, it remains distributed according to $\nu_{\text{QSD}}$.

hints.label: thm-phi-irreducibility
hints.title: φ-Irreducibility of the Euclidean Gas
hints.content:
638: :label: thm-phi-irreducibility
639: 
640: The Euclidean Gas Markov chain on $\Sigma_N^{\text{alive}}$ is **φ-irreducible** with respect to Lebesgue measure: For any starting state $S_A \in \Sigma_N^{\text{alive}}$ and any open set $O_B \subseteq \Sigma_N^{\text{alive}}$, there exists $M \in \mathbb{N}$ such that:
641: 
642: $$
643: P^M(S_A, O_B) := P(S_M \in O_B \mid S_0 = S_A) > 0
644: $$
hints.section: ## 4. Main Convergence Theorem and Quasi-Stationary Distribution
hints.raw_directive:
635: #### 4.4.1. φ-Irreducibility via Two-Stage Construction
636: 
637: :::{prf:theorem} φ-Irreducibility of the Euclidean Gas
638: :label: thm-phi-irreducibility
639: 
640: The Euclidean Gas Markov chain on $\Sigma_N^{\text{alive}}$ is **φ-irreducible** with respect to Lebesgue measure: For any starting state $S_A \in \Sigma_N^{\text{alive}}$ and any open set $O_B \subseteq \Sigma_N^{\text{alive}}$, there exists $M \in \mathbb{N}$ such that:
641: 
642: $$
643: P^M(S_A, O_B) := P(S_M \in O_B \mid S_0 = S_A) > 0
644: $$
645:

hints.label: proof-thm-phi-irreducibility
hints.content:
650: :label: proof-thm-phi-irreducibility
651: 
652: **Proof (Two-Stage Construction: Gathering + Spreading).**
653: 
654: The proof constructs an explicit path showing how to get from any starting state to any target neighborhood by combining the distinct powers of cloning (global reset) and kinetics (local steering).
655: 
656: **PART I: Define the "Core" Set**
657: 
658: Define the **core set** $\mathcal{C} \subset \Sigma_N^{\text{alive}}$ as the set of configurations where:
659: 
660: 1. **All walkers alive:** $|\mathcal{A}(S)| = N$
661: 2. **Interior concentration:** All walkers within a small ball $B_r(x_*)$ where $x_* \in \text{interior}(\mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}})$ and $\varphi_{\text{barrier}}(x) < \epsilon$ for all $x \in B_r(x_*)$
662: 3. **Low velocities:** $\|v_i\| < v_{\max}$ for all $i$
663: 4. **Positive measure:** $\mathcal{C}$ is an open set with positive Lebesgue measure
664: 
665: **Key property:** $\mathcal{C}$ is "favorable" - far from boundary, all alive, low kinetic energy.
666: 
667: **PART II: Stage 1 - Gathering to Core (Cloning as Global Reset)**
668: 
669: **Claim:** For any $S_A \in \Sigma_N^{\text{alive}}$:
670: 
671: $$
672: P(S_1 \in \mathcal{C} \mid S_0 = S_A) > 0
673: $$
674: 
675: **Proof of Claim:**
676: 
677: **Step 1: Identify the "Alpha" Walker**
678: 
679: In state $S_A$, at least one walker is alive. Among alive walkers, identify the one with minimum barrier value:
680: 
681: $$
682: i_* = \arg\min_{i \in \mathcal{A}(S_A)} \varphi_{\text{barrier}}(x_i)
683: $$
684: 
685: This "alpha" walker $i_*$ is in a favorable position.
686: 
687: **Step 2: Lucky Cloning Sequence**
688: 
689: The cloning operator proceeds through $N$ walkers sequentially. For each dead or poorly-positioned walker $j$:
690: 
691: $$
692: P(\text{walker } j \text{ selects walker } i_* \text{ as companion}) = \frac{r_{i_*}}{\sum_{k \in \mathcal{A}(S_A)} r_k} =: p_{\alpha} > 0
693: $$
694: 
695: This probability $p_{\alpha}$ is strictly positive by the reward structure (Axiom 4.2.1 in 03_cloning.md).
696: 
697: **Consider the "lucky" event** $E_{\text{lucky}}$ where:
698: - All dead walkers select $i_*$ as companion
699: - All alive walkers with $\varphi(x_j) > 2\varphi(x_{i_*})$ select $i_*$ as companion
700: 
701: The probability of this event is:
702: 
703: $$
704: P(E_{\text{lucky}}) \geq p_{\alpha}^{N-1} > 0
705: $$
706: 
707: **Step 3: Post-Cloning Configuration**
708: 
709: After cloning under $E_{\text{lucky}}$:
710: - All $N$ walkers are alive
711: - Position barycenter $\mu_x \approx x_{i_*}$ (all clones near alpha)
712: - Positional scatter $\|\delta_{x,i}\| \leq \delta_{\text{clone}}$ (inelastic collision spreads them slightly)
713: 
714: **Step 4: Perturbation and Kinetic Step**
715: 
716: The perturbation adds Gaussian noise: $x_i \gets x_i + \eta_x$, $v_i \gets v_i + \eta_v$ where $\eta_x, \eta_v \sim \mathcal{N}(0, \sigma_{\text{pert}}^2 I)$.
717: 
718: **Key fact:** Gaussian distribution has positive density everywhere. Therefore:
719: 
720: $$
721: P(\text{all } N \text{ perturbed walkers land in } B_r(x_*) \text{ with } \|v_i\| < v_{\max}) = \prod_{i=1}^N \int_{B_r(x_*)} \int_{\|v\| < v_{\max}} \phi(x-x_i, v-v_i) \, dv \, dx > 0
722: $$
723: 
724: where $\phi$ is the Gaussian density.
725: 
726: **Combining all steps:**
727: 
728: $$
729: P(S_1 \in \mathcal{C} \mid S_0 = S_A) \geq P(E_{\text{lucky}}) \cdot P(\text{perturbation lands in } \mathcal{C}) > 0
730: $$
731: 
732: ✓ **Stage 1 Complete**
733: 
734: **PART III: Stage 2 - Spreading from Core (Kinetics as Local Steering)**
735: 
736: **Claim:** For any $S_C \in \mathcal{C}$ and any open set $O_B \subseteq \Sigma_N^{\text{alive}}$, there exists $M \in \mathbb{N}$ such that:
737: 
738: $$
739: P^M(S_C, O_B) > 0
740: $$
741: 
742: **Proof of Claim via Hörmander's Theorem:**
743: 
744: **Step 1: Single-Particle Controllability**
745: 
746: Each walker evolves according to the underdamped Langevin SDE:
747: 
748: $$
749: \begin{aligned}
750: dx_i &= v_i \, dt \\
751: dv_i &= [F(x_i) - \gamma v_i] \, dt + \Sigma(x_i, v_i) \circ dW_i
752: \end{aligned}
753: $$
754: 
755: This is a **hypoelliptic system**. By **Hörmander's Theorem** (Hörmander, 1967, "Hypoelliptic second order differential equations," *Acta Math.* 119:147-171):
756: 
757: **Theorem (Hörmander):** If the Lie algebra generated by the drift vector fields and diffusion vector fields spans the entire tangent space at every point, then the transition probability density $p_t(z_0, z)$ is smooth and **strictly positive** for all $t > 0$ and all $z_0, z \in \mathbb{R}^{2d}$.
758: 
759: **Verification for our SDE:**
760: - Drift vector field: $b(x,v) = (v, F(x) - \gamma v)$
761: - Diffusion vector fields: $\sigma_j(x,v) = (0, \Sigma e_j)$ for $j = 1, \ldots, d$
762: 
763: The Lie bracket $[b, \sigma_j]$ introduces terms in the position component, and iterated brackets span $\mathbb{R}^{2d}$ (standard verification, see Hairer & Mattingly, 2006).
764: 
765: **Conclusion:** From any $(x_i, v_i)$, the single-particle process has positive probability of reaching any open neighborhood in phase space after time $\tau > 0$.
766: 
767: **Step 2: N-Particle Controllability**
768: 
769: Now consider all $N$ particles. We want to show that from $S_C$, we can reach any target configuration in $O_B$ with positive probability.
770: 
771: **Target configuration:** Let $S_B^* = ((x_1^*, v_1^*), \ldots, (x_N^*, v_N^*)) \in O_B$ be any point in the target set.
772: 
773: **Sequential driving argument:**
774: 
775: - **Phase 1 (Steps 1 to $\tau_1$):** Apply kinetic evolution. By Hörmander, walker 1 has positive probability $p_1 > 0$ of reaching a neighborhood $U_1(x_1^*, v_1^*)$ of its target.
776: - **Phase 2 (Steps $\tau_1+1$ to $\tau_2$):** Continue evolution. Walker 2 has positive probability $p_2 > 0$ of reaching $U_2(x_2^*, v_2^*)$, *while walker 1 remains in* $U_1$ with probability bounded below by $1 - \delta_1$ (continuity of the SDE).
777: - **Phase $k$:** Walker $k$ reaches $U_k$ with probability $p_k > 0$, and all previous walkers remain in their neighborhoods with probability $\prod_{j<k}(1 - \delta_j)$.
778: 
779: **Independence of noise:** Since $W_i$ are independent Brownian motions:
780: 
781: $$
782: P(\text{all } N \text{ walkers reach their targets}) \geq \prod_{i=1}^N p_i \cdot \prod_{j=1}^{N-1} (1 - \delta_j) > 0
783: $$
784: 
785: **Step 3: Avoiding Absorption**
786: 
787: During the $M$ steps of kinetic evolution from $\mathcal{C}$ to $O_B$, walkers must not cross the boundary.
788: 
789: **Safe interior property:** Since $S_C \in \mathcal{C}$ starts in a region with $\varphi_{\text{barrier}} < \epsilon$ (deep interior), and the target $S_B^* \in O_B$ is also in the alive space, we can choose trajectories that remain in the interior.
790: 
791: **Probability of staying alive:** By the boundary potential contraction (Chapter 7, Theorem 5.3.1), walkers starting in the interior with low $W_b$ have exponentially small probability of reaching the boundary in finite time:
792: 
793: $$
794: P(\text{any walker exits during } M \text{ steps} \mid S_C) \leq M \cdot N \cdot e^{-c/\tau} \ll 1
795: $$
796: 
797: for appropriate choice of $M$ and $\tau$.
798: 
799: **Taking $M$ large enough:** We can make the exit probability arbitrarily small while maintaining positive probability of reaching $O_B$:
800: 
801: $$
802: P^M(S_C, O_B) \geq P(\text{reach } O_B) \cdot P(\text{no exit}) > 0
803: $$
804: 
805: ✓ **Stage 2 Complete**
806: 
807: **PART IV: Final Assembly - Two-Stage Path**
808: 
809: Combining Stage 1 and Stage 2 via the **Chapman-Kolmogorov equation**:
810: 
811: $$
812: P^{1+M}(S_A, O_B) = \int_{\Sigma_N^{\text{alive}}} P^1(S_A, dS') P^M(S', O_B)
813: $$
814: 
815: $$
816: \geq \int_{\mathcal{C}} P^1(S_A, dS') P^M(S', O_B)
817: $$
818: 
819: $$
820: \geq P^1(S_A, \mathcal{C}) \cdot \inf_{S' \in \mathcal{C}} P^M(S', O_B)
821: $$
822: 
823: From Stage 1: $P^1(S_A, \mathcal{C}) > 0$
824: 
825: From Stage 2: $\inf_{S' \in \mathcal{C}} P^M(S', O_B) > 0$ (by compactness of $\mathcal{C}$ and continuity)
826: 
827: Therefore:
828: 
829: $$
830: P^{1+M}(S_A, O_B) > 0
831: $$
832: 
833: **This proves φ-irreducibility.** ✓

829: $$
830: P^{1+M}(S_A, O_B) > 0
831: $$
832: 
833: **This proves φ-irreducibility.** ✓

hints.label: proof-thm-aperiodicity
hints.content:
853: :label: proof-thm-aperiodicity
854: 
855: **Proof (Non-Degenerate Noise Prevents Periodicity).**
856: 
857: **Method 1: Direct Argument via Continuous Noise**
858: 
859: The kinetic operator adds continuous Gaussian noise at every step. The probability of returning to the **exact** same state is zero:
860: 
861: $$
862: P(S_1 = S_0 \mid S_0) = 0
863: $$
864: 
865: because the perturbation $\eta \sim \mathcal{N}(0, \sigma_{\text{pert}}^2 I)$ has density with respect to Lebesgue measure.
866: 
867: **Implication:** The chain cannot have any deterministic cycles $S \to S \to S \to \cdots$ of period $d$.
868: 
869: **Method 2: Contradiction Argument**
870: 
871: Suppose, for contradiction, that the chain has period $d > 1$. Then the state space decomposes into $d$ disjoint subsets $\mathcal{S}_0, \ldots, \mathcal{S}_{d-1}$ such that:
872: 
873: $$
874: P(S_1 \in \mathcal{S}_{(k+1) \mod d} \mid S_0 \in \mathcal{S}_k) = 1
875: $$
876: 
877: But from the irreducibility proof (Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-phi-irreducibility` in Section 6.4.1), we showed that from any state in $\mathcal{S}_0$, we can reach the core set $\mathcal{C}$ in **one** step with positive probability.
878: 
879: Similarly, from any state in $\mathcal{S}_1$, we can reach $\mathcal{C}$ in **one** step.
880: 
881: This means $\mathcal{C} \cap \mathcal{S}_0 \neq \emptyset$ and $\mathcal{C} \cap \mathcal{S}_1 \neq \emptyset$.
882: 
883: But if $d > 1$, we must have $\mathcal{S}_0 \cap \mathcal{S}_1 = \emptyset$ (disjoint decomposition).
884: 
885: **Contradiction.** ✓
886: 
887: Therefore, $d = 1$, and the chain is aperiodic.

hints.label: thm-main-convergence
hints.title: Geometric Ergodicity and Convergence to QSD
hints.content:
913: :label: thm-main-convergence
914: 
915: Under the foundational axioms (03_cloning.md Ch 4, this document Ch 1), the Euclidean Gas Markov chain satisfies:
916: 
917: **1. Existence and Uniqueness of QSD:**
918: 
919: There exists a unique quasi-stationary distribution $\nu_{\text{QSD}}$ on $\Sigma_N^{\text{alive}}$.
920: 
921: **2. Exponential Convergence to QSD:**
922: 
923: For any initial distribution $\mu_0$ on $\Sigma_N^{\text{alive}}$ and for all $t \geq 0$:
924: 
925: $$
926: \|\mu_t - \nu_{\text{QSD}}\|_{\text{TV}} \leq C_{\text{conv}} e^{-\kappa_{\text{QSD}} t}
927: $$
928: 
929: where:
930: - $\|\cdot\|_{\text{TV}}$ is the total variation distance
931: - $\kappa_{\text{QSD}} = \Theta(\kappa_{\text{total}}\tau) > 0$ is the convergence rate
932: - $C_{\text{conv}}$ depends on $\mu_0$ and $V_{\text{total}}(S_0)$
933: 
934: **3. Exponentially Long Survival Time:**
935: 
936: Starting from $\nu_{\text{QSD}}$, the expected time until absorption satisfies:
937: 
938: $$
939: \mathbb{E}_{\nu_{\text{QSD}}}[\tau_{\dagger}] = e^{\Theta(N)}
940: $$
941: 
942: The survival time grows **exponentially with $N$**.
943: 
944: **4. Concentration Around QSD:**
945: 
946: For any $\epsilon > 0$, there exists $N_0(\epsilon)$ such that for $N > N_0$:
947: 
948: $$
949: P(V_{\text{total}}(S_t) > (1+\epsilon) V_{\text{total}}^{\text{QSD}} \mid \text{survived to time } t) \leq e^{-\Theta(N)}
950: $$

hints.label: proof-thm-main-convergence
hints.content:
958: :label: proof-thm-main-convergence
959: 
960: **Proof Sketch.**
961: 
962: We apply standard Foster-Lyapunov theory, adapted to the quasi-stationary setting.
963: 
964: **Part 1: Existence and Uniqueness**
965: 
966: The Foster-Lyapunov drift condition ({prf:ref}`thm-foster-lyapunov-main` from Chapter 7) implies:
967: 
968: $$\mathbb{E}[V_{\text{total}}(S_{t+1}) \mid S_t] \leq (1-\kappa_{\text{total}}\tau) V_{\text{total}}(S_t) + C_{\text{total}}$$
969: 
970: By the Meyn-Tweedie theorem (Meyn & Tweedie, 2009, Theorem 14.0.1), this drift condition with:
971: - $V_{\text{total}}$ as a Lyapunov function
972: - Compact level sets (ensured by the boundary potential $W_b$ and confining potential)
973: - **φ-Irreducibility** ({prf:ref}`thm-phi-irreducibility` in Section 6.4.1) - rigorously proven via two-stage construction
974: - **Aperiodicity** ({prf:ref}`thm-aperiodicity` in Section 6.4.2) - proven via non-degenerate Gaussian noise
975: 
976: implies existence of a unique invariant measure. In the absorbing case, this becomes a unique QSD (Champagnat & Villemonais, 2016).
977: 
978: **Part 2: Exponential Convergence**
979: 
980: The drift condition implies geometric ergodicity via the **Lyapunov drift method**:
981: 
982: From any initial state:
983: $$
984: \mathbb{E}[V_{\text{total}}(S_t)] \leq (1-\kappa_{\text{total}}\tau)^t V_{\text{total}}(S_0) + \frac{C_{\text{total}}}{\kappa_{\text{total}}\tau}
985: $$
986: 
987: This exponential decay in the Lyapunov function translates (via Markov coupling techniques) to exponential convergence in total variation distance.
988: 
989: **Part 3: Survival Time**
990: 
991: The survival probability per step is bounded below:
992: 
993: $$
994: P(\text{survive one step} \mid S_t) \geq 1 - e^{-\Theta(N)}
995: $$
996: 
997: This follows from:
998: - Bounded boundary potential: $W_b \leq C/\kappa_b$ in equilibrium
999: - Concentration of walkers in the interior (far from boundary)
1000: - McDiarmid's inequality: probability of all $N$ walkers simultaneously exiting is exponentially small
1001: 
1002: Over $T$ steps:
1003: $$
1004: P(\text{survive } T \text{ steps}) \geq (1 - e^{-\Theta(N)})^T \approx e^{-T e^{-\Theta(N)}}
1005: $$
1006: 
1007: For $T = e^{\Theta(N)}$, this remains close to 1.
1008: 
1009: **Part 4: Concentration**
1010: 
1011: This follows from combining:
1012: - The Foster-Lyapunov drift (concentrates $V_{\text{total}}$ around its equilibrium)
1013: - McDiarmid's inequality (exponential tails for bounded differences)
1014: - The N-uniformity of all constants

hints.label: prop-qsd-properties
hints.title: Properties of the Quasi-Stationary Distribution
hints.content:
1022: :label: prop-qsd-properties
1023: 
1024: The QSD $\nu_{\text{QSD}}$ satisfies:
1025: 
1026: **1. Position Distribution:**
1027: 
1028: The marginal position distribution is approximately:
1029: $$
1030: \rho_{\text{pos}}(x) \propto e^{-U(x) - \varphi_{\text{barrier}}(x)} \quad \text{for } x \in \mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}}
1031: $$
1032: 
1033: Walkers are concentrated in low-potential regions, avoiding the boundary.
1034: 
1035: **2. Velocity Distribution:**
1036: 
1037: The marginal velocity distribution approaches:
1038: $$
1039: \rho_{\text{vel}}(v) \propto e^{-\frac{\|v\|^2}{2\sigma_v^2/\gamma}}
1040: $$
1041: 
1042: The Gibbs distribution at effective temperature $\sigma_v^2/\gamma$.
1043: 
1044: **3. Correlations:**
1045: 
1046: Position-velocity correlations decay exponentially:
1047: $$
1048: \mathbb{E}_{\nu_{\text{QSD}}}[\langle x - \bar{x}, v - \bar{v}\rangle] = O(e^{-\gamma \Delta t})
1049: $$
1050: 
1051: over time separation $\Delta t$.
1052: 
1053: **4. Internal Variance:**
1054: 
1055: The equilibrium variances satisfy:
1056: $$
1057: V_{\text{Var},x}^{\text{QSD}} = O(C_x/\kappa_x), \quad V_{\text{Var},v}^{\text{QSD}} = O(\sigma_v^2/\gamma)
1058: $$

hints.label: thm-equilibrium-variance-bounds
hints.title: Equilibrium Variance Bounds from Drift Inequalities
hints.content:
1064: :label: thm-equilibrium-variance-bounds
1065: 
1066: The quasi-stationary distribution satisfies explicit variance bounds derived from the component drift inequalities:
1067: 
1068: **Positional Variance Equilibrium:**
1069: 
1070: From {prf:ref}`thm-positional-variance-contraction` (cloning contraction) and kinetic drift, setting $\mathbb{E}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},x}] = 0$ yields:
1071: 
1072: $$
1073: V_{\text{Var},x}^{\text{QSD}} \leq \frac{C_x}{\kappa_x}
1074: $$
1075: 
1076: where:
1077: - $\kappa_x > 0$ is the N-uniform positional contraction rate from the Keystone Principle
1078: - $C_x < \infty$ is the additive expansion constant from cloning noise and boundary effects
1079: 
1080: **Velocity Variance Equilibrium:**
1081: 
1082: From {prf:ref}`thm-bounded-velocity-expansion-cloning` (cloning expansion) and {prf:ref}`thm-velocity-variance-contraction-kinetic` (Langevin friction), setting $\mathbb{E}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},v}] = 0$ yields:
1083: 
1084: $$
1085: V_{\text{Var},v}^{\text{QSD}} \leq \frac{C_v + \sigma_{\max}^2 d \tau}{2\gamma\tau}
1086: $$
1087: 
1088: where:
1089: - $C_v$ is the state-independent velocity expansion from inelastic collisions
1090: - $\sigma_{\max}^2 d \tau$ is the noise injection from Langevin dynamics
1091: - $2\gamma\tau$ is the friction dissipation rate
1092: 
1093: **Simplified form** (when $C_v \ll \sigma_{\max}^2 d \tau$):
1094: 
1095: $$
1096: V_{\text{Var},v}^{\text{QSD}} \approx \frac{d\sigma_{\max}^2}{2\gamma}
1097: $$
1098: 
1099: recovering the classical equipartition result.
1100: 
1101: **Boundary Potential Equilibrium:**
1102: 
1103: From {prf:ref}`thm-boundary-potential-contraction`, setting $\mathbb{E}[\Delta W_b] = 0$ yields:
1104: 
1105: $$
1106: W_b^{\text{QSD}} \leq \frac{C_b}{\kappa_b}
1107: $$
1108: 
1109: ensuring bounded boundary exposure in the QSD.
1110: 
1111: **Physical Interpretation:**
1112: 
1113: These bounds show that equilibrium variance is determined by the balance between:
1114: - **Contraction mechanisms**: Cloning (positional), friction (velocity), Safe Harbor (boundary)
1115: - **Expansion mechanisms**: Cloning noise, Langevin noise, boundary reentry

hints.label: proof-thm-equilibrium-variance-bounds
hints.content:
1121: :label: proof-thm-equilibrium-variance-bounds
1122: 
1123: **Proof.**
1124: 
1125: The equilibrium variance bounds follow immediately from the drift inequalities by setting the expected change to zero.
1126: 
1127: **Positional Variance:**
1128: 
1129: From the positional variance drift inequality (Theorem 10.3.1 in 03_cloning.md):
1130: 
1131: $$
1132: \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},x}] \leq -\kappa_x V_{\text{Var},x} + C_x
1133: $$
1134: 
1135: At equilibrium, $\mathbb{E}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},x}] = 0$, thus:
1136: 
1137: $$
1138: 0 = -\kappa_x V_{\text{Var},x}^{\text{QSD}} + C_x
1139: $$
1140: 
1141: Solving for $V_{\text{Var},x}^{\text{QSD}}$:
1142: 
1143: $$
1144: V_{\text{Var},x}^{\text{QSD}} = \frac{C_x}{\kappa_x}
1145: $$
1146: 
1147: **Velocity Variance:**
1148: 
1149: The velocity variance experiences:
1150: - Expansion from cloning: $\mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},v}] \leq C_v$ (Theorem 10.4.1)
1151: - Dissipation from friction: $\mathbb{E}_{\text{kin}}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},v}] \leq -2\gamma V_{\text{Var},v} \tau + \sigma_{\max}^2 d \tau$ (Theorem 3.3.1)
1152: 
1153: Combined per-step drift:
1154: 
1155: $$
1156: \mathbb{E}_{\text{total}}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},v}] \leq -2\gamma V_{\text{Var},v} \tau + (C_v + \sigma_{\max}^2 d \tau)
1157: $$
1158: 
1159: At equilibrium, $\mathbb{E}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},v}] = 0$:
1160: 
1161: $$
1162: 0 = -2\gamma V_{\text{Var},v}^{\text{QSD}} \tau + (C_v + \sigma_{\max}^2 d \tau)
1163: $$
1164: 
1165: Solving:
1166: 
1167: $$
